{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3593327,"name":"Eitan Dror","username":"KipodHater","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/k/f08c70/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-15T19:15:37.664Z","cooked":"

Hi, our team is planning to get two Raspberry Pis, and we already have a limelight 3G. In the limelight documentation, it is recommended to use a VRM for powering limelights only. We wanted to know if it’s possible to power the Raspberry Pis using the same VRM (since the limelight is essentially a Pi as well).
Thanks for the help!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-04-15T19:15:37.664Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":5,"reads":131,"readers_count":130,"score":51.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":499443,"topic_slug":"can-you-power-of-a-vrm-a-limelight-3g-and-2-raspberry-pies","display_username":"Eitan Dror","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":68532,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/can-you-power-of-a-vrm-a-limelight-3g-and-2-raspberry-pies/499443/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3593331,"name":"","username":"Akash_Rastogi","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/akash_rastogi/{size}/169937_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-15T19:19:10.535Z","cooked":"

I’d instead recommend this when back in stock. Reliably powered our rpi devices this season with zero issues.

The Thrifty Bot

Grapple Robotics MitoCANdria

Powered by Grapple Robotics, the MitoCANdria lives up to its name as the powerhouse of the robot, providing reliable and clean power distribution where it matters most. Its innovative dual-phase design efficiently converts input voltage to both a...

Price: USD 149.99

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-04-15T19:35:20.160Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":128,"readers_count":127,"score":30.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":499443,"topic_slug":"can-you-power-of-a-vrm-a-limelight-3g-and-2-raspberry-pies","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.thethriftybot.com/products/mitocandria","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Grapple Robotics MitoCANdria","clicks":24}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":8002,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"177 & 429 | #TeamWCP| #TeamThrifty"},"post_url":"/t/can-you-power-of-a-vrm-a-limelight-3g-and-2-raspberry-pies/499443/2","custom_user_title":"177 & 429 | #TeamWCP| #TeamThrifty","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3593340,"name":"Pedro Braga","username":"predobrega","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/predobrega/{size}/211207_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-15T19:28:14.677Z","cooked":"

All at the same time? I dont think the vrm will be able to supply all that power. A single raspberry Pi 4(I’m guessing that’s the one you have) will require about 2A, so it maxes out the VRM by itself. Maybe it could still be ok to connect the 3g to the 12v 500ma channels, but I wouldn’t rely on it.

In other words, if you have the option, get another supply.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-04-15T19:28:32.400Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":102,"readers_count":101,"score":20.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":499443,"topic_slug":"can-you-power-of-a-vrm-a-limelight-3g-and-2-raspberry-pies","display_username":"Pedro Braga","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63359,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/can-you-power-of-a-vrm-a-limelight-3g-and-2-raspberry-pies/499443/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3593345,"name":"paulonis","username":"paulonis","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/p/5fc32e/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-15T19:34:29.428Z","cooked":"

Peak current from the 5V/2A outputs is 2A total and continuous current is 1.5A total. That’s not going to be enough to run three Raspberry Pis. Raspberry Pi 3 or 4 needs a minimum of 2.5A each and 3A each is recommended. Raspberry Pi 5 should have at least 4A and 5A is recommended. You are on thin ice powering even one Raspberry Pi with a VRM. You cannot power three.

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":5,"updated_at":"2025-04-15T19:34:29.428Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":85,"readers_count":84,"score":17.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":499443,"topic_slug":"can-you-power-of-a-vrm-a-limelight-3g-and-2-raspberry-pies","display_username":"paulonis","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":22261,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/can-you-power-of-a-vrm-a-limelight-3g-and-2-raspberry-pies/499443/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3593361,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2025-04-15T19:52:26.829Z","cooked":"

The LL would work fine on the 12v 2a (1.5a continuous) port of the VRM.

One RPi might be okay on the 5v 2a (1.5a continuous) port of the same VRM. You can measure your actual current draw as that depends on the RPi model and the program that is running.

You can add a powered USB hub (or split the data and power circuits in the USB cable) for the camera to take some of the load off the VRM by using another 5v source that doesn’t have to be as robust since cameras reboot really fast after a power blackout/brownout.

Use another VRM for the third RPi and that is subject to the same cautions - measure the actual current draw before committing to buying anything.

There are other voltage regulators that have been recommended on CD with plenty of current capacity. They typically aren’t as robust as the VRM for low voltage drop out but the best ones might be adequate for you and don’t cost a lot.
